::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(haven) 
TEDS_2016 <- read_stata("https://github.com/datageneration/home/blob/master/DataProgramming/data/TEDS_2016.dta?raw=true")
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
## New Dataset with NDIR and Tax as ordinal variable##
myvars <- c("Tondu", "female", "DPP", "age", "income", "edu", "Taiwanese", "Econ_worse")
newdata <- TEDS_2016[myvars]
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
newdata$Tondu<-as.numeric(newdata$Tondu,labels=c("Unification now”, “Status quo, unif. in future”, “Status quo, decide later", "Status quo forever", "Status quo, indep. in future", "Independence now”, “No response"))
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
model1=lm(Tondu~age+edu+income,
data=newdata) 
summary(model1)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

plot(model1)
```

Q: What is the problem? Why? 
A: The DV is a 7-category nominal variable. A linear regression model does not work to predict a variable that is not numeric, but especially when the scale does not have a meaningful order and consistent spacing.The variable we are trying to predict is likely not linear.  

Q: What can be done to improve prediction of the dependent variable?
A: A logit regression could help with prediction, but that is still assuming model fit without testing for it. More important is to find a model that fits the data.Testing multiple model's ROC curves could help with prediction of the dependent variable.
